Audio bitrate has no reason to be increased.. 192kbps 5.1 2 pass HE-AAC/LC v2+ I've stated several times is already unable to be discerned from AC3 448-640kbps 5.1. There is no value to increasing it unless I attempt to get close to the master/Raw LPCM audio qualities.

I've posted the list of movies, they range from 1950's all the way up to 2012/2013. What will be posted next is entirely random to a certain extent. This will not change in the future.

What I post is what I post, repeated requests for specific things will not change things much at all, and it definitely won't if I don't even have the movies on bluray.

It costs a LOT of money to buy each bluray... something I do not have any at all atm making it impossible for me to upload movies I don't already have in my possession let alone new ones recently released.

in regards to bitrate..


increasing video bitrate by 750kbps will have no significant impact on animation.... and very little to no impact on the common film... while it would likely show a slight improvement for 1080p film that is actually 1920x1080... rather than 1920x816.... most of my tests have been relatively fruitless.. i'd have to crank the bitrate quite high before it would be nearly completely indistinguishable from a bluray...

as for audio bitrate... unless I want to try and replicate the dts-master or DD TrueHD or even 6 channel lpcm raw audio formats.... there is no advantage to bumping up the audio bitrate on a 2 pass loosely enforced bitrate encode using aac 5.1... using the above 3 as the source audio. HE-aac/lc v2+ is a super high efficient audio format... a 192kbps (if you view media info for my encodes, I don't think a single one actually ever falls below that of 225kbps average and frequent spikes to 275-325kbps is common so 192kbps isn't an accurate value but I give it as it's my base setting used)... as I was saying 192kbps aac5.1 2 pass he-aac/lc v2+ is equivalent to that of 448-640kbps AC3/dts/dd.



As for the redbox or renting... no such places exist here... even block buster and rogers rentals have been out of business here for nearly 5 years or more. And when I say here.. I mean the closest ones were 100 miles away at the time.

Either I buy.... or don't...

I have to drive 100 miles just to see a movie in a theater... so the kinda tells you how often I actually go to a theater... think it's maybe once a year kind of thing. come to think of it.. the last movie I watched in the theater was dark knight... with the joker.... so it's been quite a few years lol.

@Judas thanks for the info 1 more question judas are your fast and furious released are ripped from this and source??? http://thepiratebay.sx/torrent/6658929/The_Fast_and_the_Furious_1-5_(2001_-_2011)_1080p_multisub_[mkvon

I never use any downloaded source... I've neither the bandwidth/speed required nor the wish to use such.

Every SINGLE ONE of my encodes come DIRECTLY from a physical bluray disc I have in my bluray collection, every single one of them.

This is the ONLY way to guarantee 100% that it's the best possible flawless encode I could do with the best audio and video with given settings.

This is also the reason my encodes usually have a huge edge because they are not simply fast encoded rips that are used as a source by 99% of the other encoders doing a similar job that download the 6-12gb sources.

Everything I do is entirely my own work... I rip the bluray disc... I encode it... I manually do up the subtitles.. and I pack it. I even do the uploading of the torrent manually.

I clearly show in the description what the individual video bitrate and audio bitrates are set to. They are VBR however so they aren't likely to be EXACT. In fact I've stated repeatedly that the AAC audio is rarely ever that low and usually for the 5.1 track average 225 and peak at over 300.
